title: Learning Path: GPU crash
ai_summary: The user is experiencing GPU crashes while working in Unreal Engine 5.
ai_what_you_learn: Reduce Lumen Scene Lighting Quality to Medium or Low in Project Settings under Rendering -> Global Illumination if using Lumen.
Lower the scalability settings (Engine Scalability Settings) to 'Low' or 'Medium' to reduce GPU load during testing.
Check the Output Log for specific error messages related to the crash; they often point to the failing asset or process.
Regularly save your project (Ctrl+S) and create backups to prevent data loss from crashes.

steps.title: Step 1: Understand Project Packaging and Scalability
steps.description:
Understanding how Unreal Engine packages and scales projects can help identify potential bottlenecks that lead to GPU crashes, especially related to asset complexity or rendering settings.

👉 **Action:** Watch the 'Packaging Your Project in Unreal Engine' video to understand basic project settings that impact performance.
steps.action: Watch the 'Packaging Your Project in Unreal Engine' video to understand basic project settings that impact performance.

content.title: Packaging Your Project in Unreal Engine
content.description:
**Why this helps:** This video, while focused on packaging, touches upon project settings and scalability which directly impacts GPU usage. It gives a high-level overview of how a project is prepared for deployment, which can reveal areas to optimize for stability.

⏱️ **When to watch:** Watch from the beginning to ~5:00 to understand basic project settings and scalability. (5 minutes)

steps.title: Step 2: Diagnose Your Issue Using the Output Log
steps.description:
GPU crashes often leave traces in the Output Log. Analyzing the log will provide clues about the cause, such as specific assets or features overloading the GPU.

👉 **Action:** After a crash, immediately open the Output Log in Unreal Engine and look for red error messages or warnings preceding the crash. Note down any specific assets or systems mentioned.
steps.action: After a crash, immediately open the Output Log in Unreal Engine and look for red error messages or warnings preceding the crash. Note down any specific assets or systems mentioned.

content.title: Game Animation Sample Project | Motion Matching | Unreal Engine
content.description:
**Why this helps:** While not directly about debugging crashes, the 'Game Animation Sample Project | Motion Matching | Unreal Engine' showcases a complex project. Observing how it runs, and considering the complexity, can help you compare it to your project and identify if the complexity is the problem. Furthermore, it's a good project to use to benchmark your system and see if you can replicate the crash.

⏱️ **When to watch:** Watch the beginning ~3:00 to understand the project complexity and how it runs. (3 minutes)

steps.title: Step 3: Apply the Fix by Adjusting Scalability and Rendering Settings
steps.description:
Based on the diagnostic information, adjust scalability settings to reduce the load on the GPU. This might involve lowering resolution, shadow quality, or effects settings.

👉 **Action:** Lower the Engine Scalability Settings in the Editor Settings (Edit -> Editor Preferences -> General - Performance -> Scalability). Experiment with different settings (Low, Medium, High) to find a balance between visual quality and stability. Also, review post processing effects and shadow settings.

content.title: Animech’s Unreal for Web Plugin | Unreal Build: Automotive 2021
content.description:
**Why this helps:** Although focused on web deployment, 'Animech’s Unreal for Web Plugin | Unreal Build: Automotive 2021' implicitly demonstrates optimization techniques for running Unreal Engine on platforms with limited resources (like web browsers). The principles are applicable to diagnosing and resolving GPU crashes by reducing the rendering load.

⏱️ **When to watch:** Watch from ~2:00 to ~4:00 where they demonstrate how to reduce quality for web. (2 minutes)

steps.title: Step 4: Prevent Future Issues Through Optimization and Careful Resource Management
steps.description:
Proactively optimize your project by using LODs (Level of Detail), reducing texture sizes, and optimizing materials. Regularly profile your game to identify performance bottlenecks.

👉 **Action:** Implement LODs for complex meshes, reduce the resolution of large textures, and simplify complex materials. Use the Unreal Engine Profiler to identify performance bottlenecks and optimize accordingly.

content.title: Unreal Engine 5.2 Procedural Content Generation framework #shorts
content.description:
**Why this helps:** The 'Unreal Engine 5.2 Procedural Content Generation framework #shorts' video implicitly highlights a potential optimization technique. Procedural generation can sometimes be more efficient than using manually created assets, depending on the specific case. While this video is short, it introduces the concept of procedurally generating content that could potentially reduce the load on the GPU compared to high-poly static meshes.

⏱️ **When to watch:** Watch the entire short video for a quick overview of procedural generation. (1 minute)
